description:
using nova.network.manager.FlatDHCPManager:

fixed pool 192.168.0.0/24
floating-ip 9.3.11.240

i create 2 VMs, both are assigned IPs from the fixed IP pool.  i assign one VM the 9.3.11.240 address from the floating pool.  from the host machine ((and the other VM)), i can ping and SSH to the VM on the 9.3.11.240 address.  However, on the machine which is assigned the 9.3.11.240 address I can't ping or ssh back to itself on that address.

this is a problem for some of the Bosh and Cloudfoundry applications who run services that may want to talk-back to themselves on the assigned floating ip.


I'm running folsom on ubuntu 12.04.  i've attached my nova.conf.
title: VM can't connect to itself on it's own floating IP

comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~lameleopard

comments.content:
I was helping brad troubleshoot the issue. 

The problem was fixed by changing the 'nova-network-float-snat' rule in iptables from:

SNAT       all  --  any    eth0    192.168.0.8          anywhere             to:9.3.11.224


To

SNAT       all  --  any    any 192.168.0.8          anywhere             to:9.3.11.224

After this change I was able to SSH, curl, etc to the floating IP for the instance, from inside the instance OS. 

So this seems like a problem with the firewall rules that nova-network puts in place
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~locke105

comments.content:
Yeah, I don't think that changing from a specific interface to any is a reasonable approach. That could cause traffic that's destined for another private bridge or network to be SNAT'd to something we don't want.

If anything, I think that a new NAT rule to rewrite traffic destined for the floating IP back to the private one would be better, although that gets a little icky.

Importance-wise, this seems like it would only affect situations where the host itself is running part of the application-layer bits, so I'd tend to rank it fairly low. Any sort of agent-like functionality running on the host itself should understand the networking topology and be using the private IP addresess, right?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~danms

comments.content:
Well, I have a bunch of setups from Essex that rely on an instance being able to talk to itself on the floating IP...

This was where I got the idea to change the 'out' interface on the firewall rule. In Essex it uses 'any'. I need to do some research into originally why this was changed.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~locke105

comments.content: This new configuration causes issues with some of the Windows installations I have. Most notably Exchange. I wonder what the correct solution would be.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bolke-de-bruin

comments.content: This seems to be a regression from: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/933640 , which also describes the reasons why this should work. I'm using the work around to nat the packet when it goes to itself, but I'm not sure if that is the right approach.
